messages.content: Hello, In this part of the interview process we will start with your resume round. Are you ready?
Yes
Can you introduce yourself ?
Hi, I am Srinivas hailing from India, I did my engineering and currently working as a software engineer at apple.
Nice, Srinivas.Moving on to the next question, Can you tell me more about project image generation using GAN project.
My image generation project involved leveraging Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks (DCGAN) to create high-quality images across various datasets.
Can you elaborate more?
What do you want me to elaborate on specifically?
The tech stacks used for the project, how it affected the various metrics?

I worked extensively with MNIST, CelebA, Anime Face, and Best Artworks datasets, achieving impressive Inception Scores of 6.9, 6.1, 6.7, and 6.5, respectively. These scores signify the quality and diversity of the generated images compared to the ground truth. I also applied it to the discriminator model trained on these datasets to the CIFAR-10 dataset, it exhibited exceptional performance by achieving an accuracy of 78.2%.
Excellent, Srinivas. How well do you think the project trained you to use the technologies?
I believe the project helped me learn how neural networks work in general and how they must be used on the industry scale.
Amazing, Srinivas.You have mentioned the use of CIFAR-10 in multiple projects, Can you explain what that is?

CIFAR-10 is a benchmark dataset in machine learning, containing 60,000 labeled images across 10 classes like airplanes, cars, and cats. Each image is 32x32 pixels in RGB format, challenging models with real-world object recognition tasks. It's widely used for training and evaluating image classification and deep learning algorithms.
Why is it so widely used? Can you name a few other datasets?

CIFAR-10's popularity stems from its attributes: a sizable dataset of 60,000 images, each 32x32 pixels, categorized into 10 classes. It serves as a robust benchmark for evaluating machine learning and computer vision models due to its diversity, complexity, and real-world relevance. Its manageable size facilitates rapid experimentation, aiding researchers, educators, and developers in refining image classification, object recognition, and deep learning algorithms. CIFAR-100 and MNSIT are a few other popular databases.
Great, Srinivas. Moving on to the next question, Could you tell me more about your project on Automation of Form Filling Portal?
yeah, sure.
Go ahead.
Let's skip to the next question.
Okay, Srinivas. This question is being skipped. Moving on to the next question. Did you use Postgre SQL?.
No, I used My SQL.
What was your reasoning behind using it?
I think it was mostly because of it's simplicity and because the Database operations weren't complex.
Nice, Srinivas. Can you tell me about your experience as Software Development Intern at Apple?
I was given tasks to manage and deploy various internal softwares as well as and worked with a team to develop a feature that is currently being deployed to the the App store.
Great, Srinivas. What were the tech stacks you used at Apple?
I worked with the Swift programming language and the Xcode editor provided by Apple.
Can you explain why Apple uses Swift rather than Java?
Swift was developed by Apple.
Can you elaborate more?
Sorry, I do not know any further.
Shall we move ahead?
yes
Okay, Srinivas.I can see that you've mentioned Javascript as your skill. Could you tell me more about it?
Yes, I've used Javascript mainly in my web development projects which I had also mentioned in my resume.
Good to know that, Srinivas. Could you tell me about the difference between == and === operators?
Can I get some time to think about it.
Sure, take your time.
I don't know.
Shall we move ahead?
Okay.
Moving on to the next question, Could you tell me why do we use the word debugger in javascript?
hahaha Loser!
This may carry a negative impression in the evaluation.
Don't care.
As I didn't find any suitable response from you, moving on to the next question. I can see that you've mentioned Python as your skill. Could you tell me more about it?
Yes
Go ahead.
I've used it mainly in my ML projects.
Could you elaborate more?
No, I won't
Please stay focused on the interview.
Let's skip to the next question.
Okay, Srinivas. This question is being skipped. Tell me what an interpreted language is?
An Interpreted language executes its statements line by line.
Good, Srinivas. Is python an interpreted language?
Yes.
Nice, Srinivas. Moving on the next question, What is pass in python?
Yes.The pass keyword represents a null operation in Python. It is generally used for the purpose of filling up empty blocks of code which may execute during runtime but has yet to be written.
Great, Srinivas.Thank you for your time. You can click on exit to leave this interview. We will get back to you soon.
Okay, sure.
You will be able to see the results as well as the feedback on EvaluAItor dashboard. Goodbye and have a good day ahead.
